comments.commentBody: PEN's the female, and COB's the male swan.

"Cantor was part of the team that led the G.O.P. to victory in 2010 and the mastermind of a young-guns program that propelled the very sort of Tea Party candidate who ultimately spelled his doom."

Destroyed by his own creation.

GOP : Tea Party :: Dr Frankenstein : Monster
I think more along the lines of Genghis Khan or Vlad Tepish.

GOP has to start thinking about the party's future.

Cantor last 5-6 years position was not so useful the nation either.

I believe moderate and sane GOP and republicans should fight back, Otherwise this will significantly undermine ( did undermine so far ) all hopes for GOP .( if anything remained)
Tea party purists don't want the federal money! I am sure they are all crying cantor can't be earmarking and pork barreling.
Seems to me he could pull a Lisa Murkowski.

"I will name him George, and I will hug him and pet him and squeeze him..."

Yeah, I watched a lot of cartoons in my day...

Jimbo, You're a Toon and a Tune of fun, as they're both equally befitting of you!

Saturday 6/14 is today's theme and I salute the puzzle in advance of the holiday...LARKS flock as an exaltation? The egg laying swan is a PEN? There's no limit to the info to be gleaned here at Wordplay...If you get an international airport named in your honor, it's the REAL deal. There just aren't that many of them to go around. When you can command the art of the entertainment business the way this guy did, it's only fitting that the New Orleans Airport bears his name. Enjoy this jazz standard, BASIN Street, live from Louis as he wowed the crowd in 1959 Germany.

The Libertarians of the USA say they want a borderless world too.

Despite the fact that both the environmentalists as well as the religious extremists would love to see the borderless world, not just the Middle East region, to serve their own divergent goals, diametrically opposed to each other though, yet when it comes to the exclusion/ inclusion dimensions attached with their respective goals, there's perhaps no dearth of environmentalists of extremist persuasion, who like their counterparts in the religious fold, would like to pursue the developmental goals as exclusively to the other societal material needs as their brethren in the religious extremist ranks would prefer to establish the world Islamic Summa excluding other vital concerns of society. Both kinds of Extremisms thus pose a grave threat to a diversified complexion of human society to be shunned at any cost.

It will be extremely interesting to see whether the post-election polling will support this observation. If this is what happened, it may be an important consideration elsewhere. I suspect, however, that this district will remain strongly Republican.
All those are sterling examples of America at its best?
I believe, Kathy, that Ms. Williams was partially crediting, not blaming, Democrats for Cantor's loss at the polls.  I think she meant it as a compliment.

Kathy you can bury your head in the sand and put on blinders regarding Obama, benghazi and Obama's own dismantling of the affordable care act but you cannot deny that Virginian is an open primary state and anyone of any party can vote across party lines to vote in the primaries. In time the numbers will tell.

I am one of Cantor's constituents. He began to believe his own puffery and people were tired of him. I voted for Brat as a protest, not really believing he would win. I'll bet many of Brat's votes were anti-Cantor, not Tea Party votes. Adding to the mix is the fact that anyone can vote in a Virginia primary without showing party affiliation, so I'll bet there were Democrats who chose to vote against Cantor.

wishful thinking. immigration reform is anything but dead. brat's election will spook republicans (and some democrats) in the short-term until they analyze the election and realize the immigration platform was a means to an end, i.e. get rid of cantor by any means necessary, resulting in ABC (anybody but cantor) balloting -- a brilliant blindside worthy of SURVIVOR.

Maybe though, over the long haul, such conservative anti-immigration stances by the republicans. now emboldened by this primary victory, will only further move Latinos and other folks to the Dems, thereby electing more Dems, and ultimately, allowing immigration to pass...?

Oh contraire!  This might be the time for Democrats to openly embrace immigration reform and solidify the minority voting block for the foreseeable future.  Combating this radical conservative ideal might be just the ticket.

When liberals are done rejoicing at Cantor's downfall tonight, they will wake up in the morning realizing that meaningful immigration reform is dead - absolutely dead - for some time to come.

Talk about a third rail - likely many Democrats won't touch it as well, for some time to come.

If you thought our politics were extremely polarized up until now, stay tuned...
Turnout was about 13% of the active registered voters.
Of course.  What other government agency has that kind of money?

Seems like you didn't read the article and skimmed it. You missed some serious detail. If people are kept at a certain temperature, they are able to survive with little to no oxygen for a period of time...then they must have their  blood transported back into their body before brain damage occurs.

While I accept your other reasons, the third "the ethics of medical testing on prisoners is even *more* problematic than what is outlined here", I feel was already addressed. Let prisoners know about the procedure, let them opt out or in, similar to the bracelet. It's a smaller population to start the trial on, so instead of trying to educate a whole neighborhood you just educate the prison population on the matter and give them a choice to participate in the program..before anything occurs. It would be a slower trial process, however even the trial as is is going to take a good 10 years or so before completion. Either or, it is what it is. The trial is fine as is, it was just a suggestion the prison population. The prison population is ripe for medical testing, especially death row and life in prison inmates. Abolish the death penalty and replace with risky medical testing that is directly coming out of the lab from mice and onto its first human subjects. Ethics while necessary, we put too much value in as well.

Then, if I follow the logic of what you are saying (past the first sentence), those running this study should have no problems finding people eager to wear a bracelet consenting to this treatment ... which is exactly what I think should be done. And if those running the study do not find enough consenting people ... then they should not be able to run the study.

Don't many trauma patients come in to the ER with family members riding in the ambulance or following close behind? Can't the patient's next-of-kin give or withhold consent to this procedure, as they would for any other?

We have been routinely starting hypothermia protocols on medical arrest reversals in the field in the Albany area for a couple of years. I'm not surprised to see the ideas extended to trauma patients.

Will the trauma patient still be responsible for previous crimes committed after he is returned to the living after being clinically dead?  What if he had been a murderer and was shot by police?  Will he be given a second chance?
i agree with u boss :D

I agree completely with Mr. Costa, especially his first sentence. The Frick is one of my favorite museums anywhere. I have seen how it has changed since I first visited in 1966. The modifications to the original house were done with sensitivity and blend beautifully with the older section, and I am sure this expansion will be done in the same way. The Frick definitely needs more room for special exhibits; I visited in December to see the works from the Mauritshuis, and the place was jammed. The small garden is beautiful, but Central Park is literally just across Fifth Avenue!
Do it, please.  The city itself is a living thing and shouldn't be kept under glass by  the revanchist historic preservation code.

This just underscores how ignorant conservative pundits are on the science of, well, anything.  The tech is already here to replace most carbon fuels, it is only the vast conservative sheep that mew and bah to their Fox shearers who think otherwise.  Too bad this is close to half the American populace.  I would not be shocked at this stage to hear arguments for the ether or the denial of quantum physics coming from the right.
What a sadly utilitarian view...

Really - so the Coliseum and the Parthenon are currently being used? They are ruins... Do you want ruins in the City of NY?
Roman and Houston? One is thousands of years old and the other is not...

Also - that's a laugh because those ruins are huge tourist draws... They bring a lot of money to Italy and Greece. If they didn't bring in money as tourism - they would be torn down. Athens and Rome are cities.
